docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the AIDS epidemic was recognized in 1981, deaths from the disease in New York City dropped sharply last year, declining by 30 percent, a City Health Department official said today. Speaking at a scientific meeting here, Dr. Mary Ann Chiasson, the Assistant Commissioner for Disease Intervention Research, said that the number of people who died from the disease fell to 4,944 in 1996, from 7,046 in 1995, and that the decline occurred in all ethnic groups and in both sexes. For unknown reasons, the drop was greater among men than women.

headline.main: DEATHS FROM AIDS DECLINE SHARPLY IN NEW YORK CITY

docs.abstract: Dr Mary Ann Chiasson, Asst Health Comr in New York City, reports deaths from AIDS dropped sharply in NYC last year, declining 30%, for first time since AIDS epidemic was recognized in 1981; says that number of people who died from disease fell to 4,944 in 1996, from 7,046 in 1995, and the decline occurred in all ethnic groups and in both sexes; for unknown reasons drop was greater among men than women; Chiasson asserts that most likely explanations for decline are advances in therapy introduced in early 1990's and expanded access to medical care and services made possible by surge in government money in 1994 (M)
docs.snippet: For the first time since the AIDS epidemic was recognized in 1981, deaths from the disease in New York City dropped sharply last year, declining by 30 percent, a City Health Department official said today.     Speaking at a scientific meeting here,...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While I agree with the premise of your Jan. 21 editorial calling for reducing the cost of automobile insurance in New Jersey, I don't agree that the approach suggested by a bipartisan group in the Senate is appropriate. The proposal that victims give up the right to sue for recovery of pain and suffering damages in exchange for a lower premium introduces a system whereby the only people who can keep that privilege will be those who can afford the higher premium. Further, the sponsors' comparisons between home insurance, health insurance and auto insurance are nonsensical. Auto insurance is designed to compensate for injury inflicted by another. If your house is consumed by fire, there is no outside party responsible. And the pain and suffering from open-heart surgery comes with the turf, not because a doctor is guilty of malpractice.
docs.abstract: W David Waters letter contends that while he agrees with premise of Jan 21 editorial calling for reducing cost of automobile insurance in New Jersey, he does not agree that appraoch suggested by bipartisan group in Senate is appropriate

docs.lead_paragraph: In a unanimous decision, a panel of experts convened by the National Institutes of Health concluded today that it could not recommend that all women in their 40's have mammograms. The panel said women of that age must make up their own minds, but added that there was as yet no overwhelmingly persuasive evidence that regular breast X-rays for healthy women under 50 would save lives.
docs.abstract: National Institutes of Health panel, in unanimous decision, concludes that it cannot recommend that all women in their 40's have mammograms; says there is no overwhelmingly persuasive evidence that regular breast X-rays for healthy women under 50 will save lives; debate over value of mammograms for women in their 40's has been going on for years; there is wide agreement that screening for breast cancer with mammograms benefits women over age of 50; some experts maintain that any benefit for those in their 40's is outweighed by risk that false alarms in mammogram results will lead to unnecessary surgery; National Cancer Institute Dir Richard D Klausner, at whose behest planel had been created, says he is 'shocked' by its finding (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a wide-ranging indictment that implicates major associates of New York City's politically powerful police union, Federal authorities charged yesterday that top officials of a sister union representing the transit police took kickbacks and engaged in several other schemes before the two unions merged in 1995. The racketeering and bribery indictments were immediately seized on by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as a primary reason for his administration's failure to negotiate a new contract with the 38,000-member police union. On Tuesday, that union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, rejected the city's last contract offer, leaving the talks with the influential union at an impasse as the Mayor prepares to run for re-election.

headline.main: Heads of Former Transit Police Union Are Indicted

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors charge top aides of New York City's former Transit Police Benevolent Association took kickbacks and engaged in other schemes before union merged with Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in 1995; Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani cites racketeering and bribery indictment as key reason for his failure to negotiate new pact with PBA; indictment holds lawyers who also work for PBA paid bribes to Transit PBA aides to keep union's work; one of lawyers, James J Lysaght, is key figure in PBA contract talks; charges also involve questionable donations to former Transit PBA president Ron Reale's unsuccessful 1993 campaign for Public Advocate; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: One day after his inauguration, President Clinton made a conciliatory gesture to Congressional Republicans today by announcing that his budget proposal would contain more savings in Medicare than he was willing to consider last year. At a White House appearance before a strategy session with his economic advisers, Mr. Clinton said his budget for the 1998 fiscal year would propose trimming the growth in Medicare spending by $138 billion over six years.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton makes conciliatory gesture to Congressional Republicans by announcing that his budget proposal will contain more savings in Medicare than he was willing to consider last year; says his budget for 1998 fiscal year will propose trimming growth in Medicare spending by $138 billion over six years; when budget talks between Congress and Clinton collapsed last Jan, Republicans were seeking to rein in Medicare spending by $158 billion over six years, and Clinton had proposed $116 billion in reductions; prominent Republicans praise Clinton for meeting them halfway on Medicare savings level (M)
docs.snippet: One day after his inauguration, President Clinton made a conciliatory gesture to Congressional Republicans today by announcing that his budget proposal would contain more savings in Medicare than he was willing to consider last year.    At a White...

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a perception in some circles that everyone either is taking an antidepressant or knows someone who is taking one. Prozac and Zoloft are household words and the sales of these drugs have soared to the point where the global market for all antidepressants is estimated at $6 billion a year. But at the same time a panel of experts recently concluded that depression was still being underdiagnosed and undertreated. For most people with clinical depression, the disorder is either undiagnosed or misdiagnosed, the panel reports in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association. Of those who have been depressed for 20 or more years, about half have never taken an antidepressant, the report says, and fewer than one-third of those who take medicine get an adequate dose for a long enough time.

headline.main: Lag Seen in Aid for Depression

docs.abstract: Panel of experts from Brown University School of Medicine says that clinical depression is still being underdiagnosed and undertreated; says that of those who have been depressed for 20 or more years, about half have never taken an antidepressant and fewer than one-third of those who take medicine get an adequate dose for a long enough time; drawing (L)
